newsitem.title: CANADA: Air Canada, Canadian get new routes.
newsitem.headline: Air Canada, Canadian get new routes.

text.p: Canadian Transport Minister David Anderson and Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said Canadian Airlines International has been designated to serve Chile, the Dominican Republic, Russia and Spain, while Air Canada has been designated to serve Greece.
"The federal government is expanding access to foreign destinations for Canadian carriers," Anderson said in a statement.

Axworthy said the designations reflect the growth of Canadian business opportunities around the world, will benefit Canada's international trade and travel industries through increased access to foreign markets.

All five markets became contestable under the "use it or lose it" provisions of the government's 1994 International Air Transportation Policy because service had either not been initiated within the required time frame or was below the minimum requirements of the policy, the government said.

In each case, the government initiated a call for service proposals in response to a request for designation from an interested Canadian carrier. Carriers were then selected on the basis of an assessment of the proposals received.
Air Club International has been named "back-up" carrier for Chile and Canadian Airlines International back-up carrier for Greece, the transport department said.

Where negotiation with a foreign country is not required for the implementation of service, a carrier has one year to introduce services. Otherwise, the routes become either available to the back-up carrier, if it is willing to initiate service, or contestable by other Canadian carriers.

The department said in cases where negotiations are necessary for the introduction of service, the government's air policy allows carriers one year from the date of selection to initiate service, or six months from the establishment of the relevant air agreement.
